Subject: EgTest: quick & easy unit tests
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=9541334; y=QrhwJt5ySt4BfkAmT592ZwtHEKA6UIv-BUjcH3DNDPAChg
X-Original-From: David Leppik <david@...>
Reply-To: David Leppik <david@...>
X-Original-Return-Path: David Leppik <david@...>
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
X-Yahoo-Newman-Property: groups-system
X-Yahoo-Newman-Id: groups-system
X-eGroups-Approved-By: dsaff via web; 24 Mar 2017 15:04:33 -0000
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="UTF-8"
From: David Leppik <david@...>

I have a new framework which combines unit tests and documentation in sourc=
e code. The goal is to make unit testing "excuse-free:" i.e. so simple that=
 they become the lazy way to spot-check code, while ensuring that examples =
in Javadoc are automatically tested.


This is a complementary way to write=
 certain simple tests, rather than a full-on replacement for hand-writing J=
Unit tests.




https://github.com/dleppik/EgTest




A quick example; this=
 would be found in a main (non-test) Java file:


@Eg(given =3D {"1", "2"},=
 returns =3D "3")
@Eg(given =3D {"1", "Integer.MAX_VALUE"}, returns =3D "In=
teger.MIN_VALUE")
static int add(int a, int b) {
    return a + b;
}


The =
above annotations show up in Javadoc and they produce a JUnit test which te=
sts the assertions on the add method.


Any feedback would be extremely wel=
come. This is early enough that it's not too late to change the syntax or n=
omenclature if there's a better way to go about it.




	-Dave


--
David L=
eppik                                     http://www.leppik.net/david/blog/=

david@...

subject: EgTest: quick & easy unit tests
